title: replace jsonstream with JSONStream
body:
NPM has confused opinions about cases of names of modules when publishing. Some operating systems are also confused by lowercase names, and the presence of JSONStream and jsonstream in the same tree is possible. However, today one bug saves us from another and npm only checks the name validation in the client! so I have published new versions of the uppercase version.
- [x] browser-pack substack/browser-pack#57
- [x] deps-sort substack/deps-sort#5
- [x] insert-module-globals substack/insert-module-globals#44
- [x] module-deps substack/module-deps#84

https://github.com/dominictarr/JSONStream/issues/68

this issue supercedes https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/1247

title: browser field in package.json no longer works
body:
In package.json I have

``` JSON
"browser": {
    "rampage": "./rampage/static-dev/js/rampage.js"
}
```

In browserify <10.1.1 I could then use .add('rampage') just fine, now however it errors out:

```
Error: Cannot find module '*snip*/rampage' from '*snip*'
    at *snip*/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:55:21
    at load (*snip*/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:69:43)
    at onex (*snip*/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:92:31)
    at *snip*/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:22:47
```

I can't test 10.1.1 to be certain because of the JSONStream changes, I can't even roll back to a working browserify version because of that as well. This was most definitely working in 10.1.0 though.

title: cannot install browserify using npm on os x 10.10
body:
I installed node and npm using this information: https://gist.github.com/DanHerbert/9520689
`node: v0.12.0
 npm: 2.9.0`

However, still, when I try to install browserify with `npm install -g browserify`, I get this:

```
bash-3.2$ npm install -g browserify
npm ERR! Darwin 14.3.0
npm ERR! argv "node" "/Users/iwo/.node/bin/npm" "install" "-g" "browserify"
npm ERR! node v0.12.0
npm ERR! npm  v2.9.0
npm ERR! code ETARGET

npm ERR! notarget No compatible version found: JSONStream@'>=1.0.3 <2.0.0'
```

Could someone please enlighten me? Thanks!

title: Make sure entry paths are always full paths
body:
When using the CLI, entry files were always resolved to absolute paths, but when using the API, they weren't. module-deps respects the `row.file` on its initial rows insofar that it resolved relative paths (based on `opts.basedir`) but it didn't rewrite it on the `row`. This led to a weird behavior with watchify where entry files were never being pulled from the cache - unless you used the CLI or passed in an absolute path via the API.

Using `basedir` to resolve the path is consistent with @substack's view on path resolution ("require vs entry" in https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/1219#issuecomment-96126563).

This PR also adds a few tests that use the relative path behavior and extends others to verify that `row.file` is always the absolute path. 

cc: @jmm @terinjokes

title: Replace JSONStream with jsonstream
body:
NPM now has opinions about names of modules when publishing. We have an internal NPM registry and cannot sync browserify to is due to this dependency. No fear, @dominictarr has published a lowercase version.
- [x] browser-pack https://github.com/substack/browser-pack/pull/57
- [x] deps-sort https://github.com/substack/deps-sort/pull/5
- [x] insert-module-globals https://github.com/substack/insert-module-globals/pull/44
- [x] module-deps https://github.com/substack/module-deps/pull/84

title: package.json configuration ignored when using STDIN as source
body:
package.json

``` js
{
    "browserify": {
        "transform": ["src"]
    }
}
```

This works
`browserify -t coffee-reactify --extension=".cjsx" node_modules/src/index.cjsx > assets/scripts/main.js`

This doesn't
`cat node_modules/src/index.cjsx | cjsx -sbp | browserify -t coffee-reactify --extension=".cjsx" -`
Error

```
x/x/x/publicwall/node_modules/src/hell.cjsx:1
module.exports = name : "ali", age: 25
                      ^
ParseError: Unexpected token

```

title: Bump module-deps to ^3.7.10
body:
```
#10.1.1

* Updates module-deps to ^3.7.10, which fixes an issue where under certain conditions the directory for a `package.json` would be attributed to the wrong package. [substack/module-deps#81](https://github.com/substack/module-deps/pull/81) (thanks @pmowrer)
```

title: Remove unnecessary "isDedupe" json check
body: watchify doesn't cache when "deps" are emitted, it caches module-deps' output - which would be the preprocessed json.

title: Ability to specify extension for STDIN for transforms to work
body:
File created by browserify when using stdin has .js extension (its named something like " _stream_0.js" ).
Please add the feature to specify specific extension for this file if reading from stdin. Transforms like coffee-reactify require .cjsx or .coffee file extensions to apply themselves to the stream if file isn't these extension its content is ignored by the transform.

title: Browserify + NodeWebkit - how to unblock the fs module?
--no-browser-field and --node
body:
This patch adds support for `--no-browser-field` to turn off the package.json browser field machinery. This is useful if you are targeting a node environment with the bundle, such as [code coverage](https://npmjs.com/package/coverify), to apply transforms to server code, or to target other platforms like chrome apps.

This feature is also available as `opts.browserField = false`. `--node` is added as an alias for `--bare` and `--no-browser-field`.

title: Fixed #899 - browserify removes output file if it didn't exist previously
body: The change is trivial. I didn't use fs.exists() because it's being deprecated soon according to the recent Node documentation.

title: bundler.exclude('jquery') followed by bundler.require('jquery')
bundler.require() errors uncatchable
Specify browser paths in a separate file instead of package.json
browserify + chrome extension's getBackgroundPage()
body:
I'm using browserify to manage a Chrome extension, and while in general it appears to work well, there's a problem that comes with browserify embedding the library code in the spaghetti carbonara that is

```
(function e(t,n,r){function s(o,u){if(!n[o]){if(!t[o]){var a=typeof require=="function"&&require;if(!u&&a)return a(o,!0);if(i)return i(o,!0);var f=new Error("Cannot find module '"+o+"'");throw f.code="MODULE_NOT_FOUND",f}var l=n[o]={exports:{}};t[o][0].call(l.exports,function(e){var n=t[o][1][e];return s(n?n:e)},l,l.exports,e,t,n,r)}return n[o].exports}var i=typeof require=="function"&&require;for(var o=0;o<r.length;o++)s(r[o]);return s})({1:[function(require,module,exports){
[...]
```

I noticed that, unlike advertised, e.g., [here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/9538625/353337), that you can't access variables defined in a background page (`chrome.extension.getBackgroundPage()`).

I'm not sure what kind of magic (if any) is behind `chrome.extension.getBackgroundPage()`, but maybe someone else has an idea.

title: directories.lib support
body:
Good day!

I'm working on a JavaScript package, say `framework`. Its  distribution files are in `dist/` directory. I'm `browserify`ing my application uses `framework`: `var component = require('framework/component');`, it's trying to find `framework/component.js` file but not `framework/dist/component.js`.

As I know, `package.json`'s [`directories.lib`](https://docs.npmjs.com/files/package.json#directories-lib) option can help me. But seems like `browserify` ignores it.

Am I correct or no? Thanks.

title: IntelliJ / Webstorm / IDEA sourcemap debugging compatibility?
body: I use Intellij IDEA and am unable to get debugging working with browserify's sourcemaps. The people at JetBrains think it's a browserify problem, as there have been a [couple](https://devnet.jetbrains.com/message/5540299#5540299) of [issues](https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/WEB-14454) posted about that already. I have the same issue as the second link - maps are found and correctly linked, but breakpoints not hit. Does anyone here think this is a browserify issue or a JetBrains issue? Probably the right person on each side would be able to figure this one out.

title: PR / Issue organization
body:
How about we borrow some of [these](https://github.com/facebook/react/labels) labels?

I think these are useful:

```
GH: Review-needed <-- Another collaborator needs to look at it (but one already did)
GH: Needs-revision  <-- Something wrong with a PR that the author should fix
GH: Accepted   <-- Ready to be merged for the next release

Duplicate
Invalid
Wontfix

Reconsider <-- Kinda like a hopeful "wontfix"
Bug (already exists) 
Feature Request (already exists)
Question (already exists as Support)
```

---

Also, the issue backlog is pretty long. I noticed both of you have been going through the old stuff. I think we should focus on the newer stuff since those ppl probably moved on or found a workaround. I propose that we declare "issue bankruptcy" on almost everything from before 2015.

cc: @terinjokes @jmm

title: Update process to ~0.11.0
body:
Fixes https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/1179. This also solves my major-version-bump dilemma from https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/1230 because this merits it for sure.

The reason for having to pass in `clearTimeout` into the context in tests is because there is now a queue in `process.nextTick` that depends on it (see https://github.com/defunctzombie/node-process/pull/38 and https://github.com/defunctzombie/node-process/compare/v0.10.1...v0.11.0.).

cc: @jmm @terinjokes

title: Update deps
body:
- The update of defined and xtend are so we can get npm to dedupe them. It's already in https://github.com/substack/insert-module-globals/pull/42, https://github.com/substack/deps-sort/pull/4, https://github.com/substack/module-deps/pull/82 and https://github.com/substack/browser-pack/pull/56.
- I'm also updating and pinning punycode to 1.3.2 for deduping purposes. But I chose to not make it floating since [url](https://github.com/defunctzombie/node-url/blob/v0.10.3/package.json#L6) also has it pinned there.
- And I'm updating module-deps, despite that the `^` already covers the version, so that over in watchify I can count on https://github.com/substack/module-deps/pull/80 always being in whatever is the next browserify version we publish.

The motivation for the deduping is https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/707#issuecomment-96273418.

---

@jmm and @terinjokes: This should be published as 9.0.9. But since https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/1222 hasn't been published, strict semver dictates that we move to 10.0.0. I think that's over kill for removing the "v" flag. I'll hold off publishing until you chime in.

title: Acorn all the things!
body:
- PR: https://github.com/substack/node-syntax-error/pull/8 - bumps acorn from ~0.9.0 to ^1.0.3
- PR: https://github.com/substack/node-detective/pull/46 - bumps acorn from ~0.9.0 to ^1.0.3
- Issue: https://github.com/substack/lexical-scope/issues/21 tracks updating astw from ~1.1.0 to what should be ^2.0.0 after https://github.com/substack/astw/pull/7
  - PR: https://github.com/substack/astw/pull/7 - switches from esprima^2.1.0 to acorn^1.0.3

I know it's a long shot to get all these merged, but I'm trying anyway. Now that acorn is 1.x.x it can float with ^. And should go some ways towards helping with the bloat discussed in https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/707.

title: checking for the existence of Buffer causes it to exist
body:
Some modules check for the existence of Buffer but don't require it to work. Because the identifier `Buffer` is seen by browserify, it becomes bundled. Buffer addes quite a lot of code to a bundle that often isn't needed. (About 40kB)

An example of this is if you require [clone](https://www.npmjs.com/package/clone), which checks if `Buffer` exists, and therefore causes it to be added to a browserified bundle. 

It would be handy to be able to explicitly tag that your module does not require Buffer in the package.json (even if you use the `Buffer` identifier in your source) to allow for it to be not added if possible.

title: Don't run noParse files through transforms
body: If files are included in noParse, they should be excluded from the transforms. If I want to avoid parsing a library like jQuery, then I don't want to send it through Babel or ngAnnotate either.

title: Update constructor docs.
body:
Fix #1221. You can see it [rendered here](https://github.com/jmm/node-browserify/blob/e7db329e96febc82dbfd87711626e57da6632015/readme.markdown).

I think eventually _file object_ and _entry file_ should be better defined in the docs.

title: AMD dependencies
readme: document opts.transform
Debowerify seems to be broken when used with external libraries in v9.0.3+
Remove 'v' shortcut for version
body:
This is part of an effort to bring consistency to the browserify and watchify flags (as somewhat discussed in https://github.com/substack/watchify/pull/204#issuecomment-93759292).

watchify already uses "v" for "verbose", and has no "version" flag. By removing the (arguably) seldom used "v" from browserify, (1) watchify can fully "own" it, and (2) can add a "version" flag without clashing with browserify's short form of it. Also, a lot of unix tools don't have a "v", just "version".

Alternatively, "v" could be replaced with "V" - [ssh](http://linux.die.net/man/1/ssh), [less](http://linux.die.net/man/1/less), among other do this.

cc: @jmm

title: Constructor signature: `files` *and* `opts`?
body: The documented constructor signature is `(files=[] or opts={})`, but in reality you can pass `files` **and** `opts` -- `(files, opts)` -- and I'm pretty sure in the wild people do that all the time. Is there a notion the 2-arg signature may go away, or can that be documented and supported? It's not a big deal, but it's a bit more convenient, particularly when you have a single entry file and are setting some options. It's already implemented and if that's likely to continue it would be nice to just document it.

title: Constructor `opts.require` (keep, document, fix?; kill?)
body:
The constructor currently accepts an undocumented `opts.require` prop. I assume it's a holdover from an earlier version? In any case, can it be either documented and fixed or dropped? Personally I like the idea of having it, if there's not some good reason not to.

It's somewhat broken currently (v9.0.8):

``` js
var
  browserify = require('browserify'),
  fs = require('fs'),
  files = [{file: './a'}];

browserify()
  .require(files)
  .bundle()
  .pipe(fs.createWriteStream('./bundle-a1.js').on('finish', function () {
    browserify({require: files})
      .bundle()
      .pipe(fs.createWriteStream('./bundle-a2.js'));
  }));
```

The first produces a good `bundle-a1.js`, the second produces `TypeError: Arguments to path.resolve must be strings` and empty `bundle-a2.js`.

title: CLI path resolution inconsistent for entry files and -e|--entry vs. -r|--require
body:
In browserify 9.0.8 CLI on linux path arguments are resolved inconsistently for entry files / `-e` / `--entry` vs `-r` / `--required`.  Seems counterintuitive. Is there a reason to resolve them differently? Note: triggering it doesn't require an `expose` argument for the `-r` files.

```
# Module files a.js and b.js

# Error: Cannot find module 'b'
browserify a -r b
browserify -e a -r b

# No error, both bundled
browserify a -r ./b
browserify -e a -r ./b
```

title: Array support for b.exclude() and b.ignore()
body: Simple usability enhancement to prevent long exclude/ignore chains.

title: gulp + vinyl-transform + browserify - broken, last working 9.0.4
Closure.js Support
body:
I tried using browserify with a the libphonenumber package which uses closure.js. When I require it the browser throws an error: 

```
Uncaught TypeError: fs.readFileSync is not a function
```

Is this a known limitation or is there a workaround for this?

title: Unnecessary code in the micro loader?
"browserify -t brfs index.js > bundle.js" throws "ParseError: Unexpected token"
version >= 9.0.3 fails with gulp and vinyl-transform
camelCased standalone
body: Why is the standalone name camelCased? Rather annoying when the module exists as `/module-name/` in the file system. Exposing the same standalone name is impossible as it will become `moduleName`

title: Sanitize json modules
body: Not all valid JSON is valid JS. http://timelessrepo.com/json-isnt-a-javascript-subset

title: Note that opts.standalone will be camelized on window if it's hyphenated
firefox content-script global object is used instead of window, leads to exceptions
body:
Browserify uses 

`typeof global !== "undefined" ? global : typeof self !== "undefined" ? self : typeof window !== "undefined" ? window : {}`

to detect `global` variable, and, in most cases that is fine, however, certain environments (content-script of firefox plugin for instance) has a read-only object as a `global` instead. This obviously results in errors and renders browserify useless. How can this be improved?

title: Optimizing incremental bundle time
body:
Lately I've been doing some profiling with [node-webkit-agent](http://c4milo.github.io/node-webkit-agent/) to see where the bundle time is spent on watchify rebundle. It tends to get fairly slow in large projects (current app is more than 1 second per rebundle).

The obvious impact comes from inline source maps. Turning those off reduces the re-bundle time to 100ms.

The next thing I noticed is [syntax-error](https://github.com/substack/node-syntax-error). This runs `eval()` on the source of _every file_ across your bundle, even if they haven't changed. In my case, re-bundle time goes from ~1000ms (with syntax-error) to ~700ms (without). 

Having both of these things only triggered on files that change (rather than across the entire bundle) would probably bring 1000ms re-bundles down to < 100ms.

title: Aliased dependencies are not passed to transform when added to bundle via .require or .add
body:
> [Repo demonstrating this issue](https://github.com/bendrucker/browserify-shim-issue-152)

I noticed this issue when working with the [`browserify-shim`](https://github.com/thlorenz/browserify-shim) transform, and reported in thlorenz/browserify-shim#152.

If there is a `package.json` anywhere in the path of an alias defined in the `browser` field, it will be treated as if it came from `node_modules`, and thus not passed to the transform.

title: Look for transform modules in global node modules
body:
Steps to reproduce issue:
1. Install 'coffeeify' globally: `npm install -g coffeeify`
2. Try to run browserify with coffeeify: `browserify -t coffeeify`
3. Browserify complains that it can't find coffeeify in the local directory.

Same with any transform module. Browserify only finds transforms if they are installed locally.

I shouldn't have to install coffeeify locally in each separate app. Please make transform lookup check the global node modules also.

title: Accept glob string for [entry files] ...
body:
...in command "browserify [entry files] {OPTIONS}"
Windows does not auto expand globs on the command line

Creating the pull request to try and progress. It works locally for me, but an automated test case would be awesome. I can't tell how to make such a test case examining the existing suite.

This pull request is for https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/1170

title: How to exclude all node_modules?
body:
Hi. I want to create a bundle without any modules from node_modules being bundled, and I have a lot so I can't just ignore them all one at a time. 

I'm only using this bundle as a transpiled (6to5) source for generating translation files (gettext) so I don't need all the external dependencies to slow down the build.

title: 9.0.8 breaks 'dep' event
body:
Since 'dep' isn't documented in the browserify readme, maybe this was intentional, but it's causing grief for me, so I thought I'd raise it in case it wasn't.  :)

In browserify 9.0.7, if I did:

```
b = browserify(opts);
b.on('dep', function(dep) {
    console.log(dep.id + " -- " + dep.file);
});
```

then I'd get output like:

```
backbone.layoutmanager -- /Users/jwalton/project/node_modules/backbone.layoutmanager/backbone.layoutmanager.js
```

In 9.0.8, I get:

```
backbone.layoutmanager -- backbone.layoutmanager
```

`dep.file` is not actually a file here.  I'm using [uber-watchify](https://github.com/benbria/uber-watchify), which tries to `fs.statSync(dep.file)`, which is obviously going to end in tears for all concerned.

title: Fix expose field for external modules and builtins
body:
Added the 'file' field at row creation in require() for external modules and builtins.
Added two tests cases.
Unnested ternary operators (style only).
Fix current https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/850
Feedback very welcome !

title: Is stdin piping still working?
body:
https://gist.github.com/substack/8078762

That doesn't seem to work anymore to me?

title: Pushing a stream to 'wrap' in the internal pipeline broke in 9.0.5
body:
Making the [output bundle readonly](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/1187) seems to break a feature that is very important to Mochify (See issue https://github.com/mantoni/mochify.js/issues/80).

When I push a stream to `b.pipeline.get('wrap')`, the stream is not part of the browserify output. The pipeline modification is done before the call to `bundle()`.

Please advice if there is anything I can do to work around the issue.

title: Error in 9.0.6+ seems related to readonly streams
body:
Hey. We use browserify via gulp to build a libs.js containing all our 3rd party deps. This works fine in 9.0.4, but in 9.0.6 and 9.0.7 I get:

```
_stream_readable.js:524
    var ret = dest.write(chunk);
                   ^
TypeError: undefined is not a function
    at Producer.ondata (_stream_readable.js:524:20)
    at emitOne (events.js:77:13)
    at Producer.emit (events.js:166:7)
    at Producer.Readable.read (_stream_readable.js:356:10)
    at flow (_stream_readable.js:734:26)
    at resume_ (_stream_readable.js:714:3)
    at _stream_readable.js:701:7
    at process._tickDomainCallback (node.js:366:13)
```

title: exception: browserify + vinyl-transform
Requiring standalone bundle generated by browserify --s within browserify project
body:
So, I've created a library that I decided to package up using browserify --s in order to create a UMD shimmed module and all is good.

However, while the shim allows it to be loaded in a bunch of different scenarios (CommonJS, AMD, Window) it appears it cannot be consumed within another browserify project.

My hunch is that running browserify simply follows requires all the way down when bundling rather than taking into account the nesting 'require' contexts that seems to be handled by the https://github.com/substack/browser-pack/blob/master/prelude.js in the generated library bundle. Thus when it get's inside the library it looks for files required inside it and expects them to be within the consuming project due to the path provided.

I guess I'm wondering if this is a bug or if I'm doing something wrong?
Any pointers would be appreciated, thanks.

title: 9.0.6 breaks build
body:
I'm using gulp with browserify and the 9.0.6 breaks my build.  This is the error I'm getting:

```
_stream_readable.js:583
    var written = dest.write(chunk);
                       ^
TypeError: Object #<Readable> has no method 'write'
    at write (_stream_readable.js:583:24)
    at flow (_stream_readable.js:592:7)
    at _stream_readable.js:560:7
    at process._tickCallback (node.js:415:13)
```

I fixed it by putting `"browserify": "=9.0.4",` in my package.json, but I just wanted to let people know that 9.0.6 (and 9.0.5) have breaking changes in it.

title: Fix #1194
body:
since 9.0.6, `bundle()` returns a read-only stream by `var output = readonly(this.pipeline)`

but if `this._bundled` is true, a 'reset' will be triggered, which cause the
problem mentioned in #1194, because `this.pipeline !== output` after `this.reset()`, they are not the same thing anymore.

title: 9.0.6 : Cannot catch errors + have to call bundle() twice
body:
Hey, 

I have 2 issues in my gulp + watchify + browserify setup with the latest browserify build. Reverting back to browserify 9.0.4 fixed the issues:
- after any watchify update, I have to call `bundle()` twice to get my changes in the generated bundle
- I can no longer catch bundle() errors (with `on('error')`)

Here is the relevant piece of my Gulpfile: https://gist.github.com/cblavier/887346babc2ff173dfaf

Thanks,
Christian

title: Deduplication and modules with stateful initialization
body:
As I understand it, deduplication works on a per-file rather than per-package basis so a Browserify build with two dependencies, A and B, one of which uses package C v.1.0 and the other using package C v.1.0.1 with some minor bugfix can end up deduplicating most of the files in C but not all of them.

This reduces the size of the bundle but can cause some very confusing issues if package C has stateful initialization code - see https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/2402#issuecomment-89234482 for an example in the context of a large library.

I'd suggest that it would be safer to deduplicate only at the package level, or perhaps not even deduplicate at all by default and require the user to specifically opt-in to deduplication of packages where they know there are unavoidable version conflicts. Thoughts?

title: Sourcemap "sources" don't contain paths to all sources
body:
I'm new to browserify and am using it for an angular project. My project structure is similar to the one found here: https://github.com/jakemmarsh/angularjs-gulp-browserify-boilerplate.
I'm using version 9.0.6 of browserify. I'm having problems generating a source map for the bundled file generated by browserify.
I'm generating source maps for my bundle like so:

```
$ browserify --debug js/pure/apps/page/page.js -t browserify-ngannotate | exorcist page.js.map > page.js
```

Here is the relevant portion of the page.js.map file:

```
"sources": [
    "../../../../npm/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-pack/_prelude.js",
```

title: 9.0.6 breaks my gulp + watchify setup
fix b.require(stream, opts)
global object when window.global is defined
body: It seems that the global object can be `window.global` as opposed to `window` when it exists. This is a problem when some third party javascript decides to insert `<div id="global">`, and now two scripts can't refer to the same global object.

title: stream returned from b.bundle() should be readonly.
body: Ensure the output of this method and event match the documentation, per #1044.

title: Add support for ES6 import syntax
body:
This might be a long shot but I'd like to see this in browserify.

The ES6 module syntax has a few nice features compared to commonJS `require` method,
namely [bindings](https://github.com/esperantojs/esperanto/wiki/Bindings) and [cyclic dependencies](https://github.com/esperantojs/esperanto/wiki/Cycles).

Since these things are in the ES6 standard it seems reasonable to work them into browserify too!

Note that just using a ES6 to ES5 transpiler wouldn't work in this case because these are cross module concerns. 
For instance, `babelify` is only able to transpile `import foo from 'foo'` to `var foo = require('foo')` at file-level, but this does not allow cyclic dependencies.

The [Esperanto](https://github.com/esperantojs/esperanto) project has a nice way of handling things but lacks too many features to be a valid replacement for browserify.

Is there any possibility to see support for ES6 `import` syntax come to browserify?

title: external and require generating different hashes for react/addons, causing bundles to break
body:
When my external build is built I end up with the hash [nv2Kki](https://github.com/octatone/notifier-for-reddit/blob/react-external/extension/js/vendor/external.js#L68) for `react/addons`.

When my main bundle is built, it is referencing `react/addons` with the hash [yutbdK](https://github.com/octatone/notifier-for-reddit/blob/react-external/extension/js/browserAction.js#L62).

This of course leads to an `Uncaught Error: Cannot find module 'yutbdK'` error emitted from my `external.js` bundle.

If I manually find and replace `yutbdK` in my main bundle with `nv2Kki`, then everything works.

[Here is my gulpfile](https://github.com/octatone/notifier-for-reddit/blob/react-external/gulpfile.js) for building these two files.

title: Accept glob string for [entry files]
More OS-agnostic tests, less dust in temporary folder
body:
Use path.join() to get local styled filepath.
Use Temp package to create temporary folders on OS specific place,
plus wiping stuff after tests.
Provide node-executable location to spawn().

title: Grab expose field specified after last colon, handling Windows
body:
Take care of the colon used as drive specifier under Windows.
Add corresponding test case to test/args.js

title: Duplicate id for the same dependency
body:
I'm playing with Browserify and React today and in my bundle I'm noticing that React is loaded with 2 different dependency number. One is 158 and the other is 314.

In the bundle file, I can see this for 314

```
314:[function(require,module,exports){
arguments[4][158][0].apply(exports,arguments)
},{"./lib/React":187,"dup":158}]
```

158 is basically just a shortcut for `module.exports = require('./lib/React');` which is 187.

My code is broken because of that, because it loads the dependency twice.

title: Browserify task only runs once in container
Q stops working with Browserify >= 8.1.0 due to nextTick changes
body:
Q works fine with Browserify 8.0.3 but has serious problems since 8.1.0.
This is related to changes done in nextTick implementation of node-process: https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/1018

Related Q issue: https://github.com/kriskowal/q/issues/669

I don't know who of Q or Browserify should fix this but this makes Q unreliable in production.

title: React Cannot find module 'envify'
problem external bundling with relative path from that
body:
Browserify pretty work well with a relative path from external package like

``` js
var bluebird = require('bluebird');
var timers = require('bluebird/js/main/timers'); // unclear way but work well with both of node.js and browserify
```

however, it doesn't fit with external bundling behaviour.

is there any ad-hoc?

title: Document opts.paths in api
body:
There are several bundles in a project I am working on, each created with different `NODE_PATH` variable when calling `browserify`. 

I wanted to generate the bundles from single node process using browserify api (repective watchify, but that is irrelevant to this PR), and without knowing about `paths` option that was impossible.

I noticed that in #767 it is mentioned that `paths` option is deprecated because `NODE_PATH` is deprecated. From looking at node documentation, it does not seem to me that `NODE_PATH` is deprecated, and I believe it is handy to have an api options with equivalent functionality.

If it is deprecated, we could still document it, but mark it as deprecated with explanation why.

FYI: 
npm WARN deprecated native-buffer-browserify@2.0.17: please use  (https://www.npmjs.org/package/buffer) instead. this module was

title: Using Fluidbox with Browserify
require option breaks standalone option (regression in v9)
body:
on less.js we had this setup

```
                src: ['./lib/less-browser/bootstrap.js'],
                options: {
                    exclude: ["promise"],
                    require: ["promise/polyfill.js"],
                    browserifyOptions: {
                        standalone: 'less'
                    }
                },
```

we have require("promise") for node - which is ignored and then a polyfill.

it seems that in v9 when the require option is set, window.less is set to `{}`

It seems I can work-around it by doing

```
// shim Promise if required
require('promise/polyfill.js');
```

in the browser bootstrap and getting rid of the require in the build config.

It used to be that excluding promise also excluded `promise/polyfill.js` hence why I needed the option - seems that is no longer the case either.

Are these 2 things expected?

title: What roles are rec.id and rec.file supposed to play?
body:
In browserify's public methods (like `b.add()` and `b.require()`) and the pipeline, what are the respective roles of `rec.id` and `rec.file` (or `row.id` and `row.file`) supposed to be? I'd like to clarify this, document what's appropriate, and if necessary / possible perhaps even simplify the logic around these props.

Throughout browserify and the pipeline they do this strange dance where sometimes they're used sort of interchangeably and other times not and their meanings can vary in confusing ways depending on input provided to browserify and pipeline phase. One explanation that could make sense is if `rec.id` is equivalent to the `id` in `require('id')` and `rec.file` is the resolved pathname (when it's a file on disk), but they're not consistently used that way. `rec.id` is also involved in the logic for linking and exposing modules. Examples:

Suppose I have these files:

`entry.js`

``` js
console.log(require('./dep').msg);
```

`dep.json`

``` json
{"msg": "This is dep.json"}
```
- The `json` pipeline phase tests only the `file` value for `/\.json$/`.
- If I do `browserify('./entry').bundle()` I get a bundle that logs "This is dep.json".
  
  In this case module-deps parses the `require('./dep')` and pushes a row like `{id: '/abs/path/to/dep.json', file: '/abs/path/to/dep.json'}`. `json` pipeline phase recognizes it as JSON. 
- If I do `browserify().require('./dep', {expose: 'DEP'})` I get `SyntaxError: Unexpected token`.
  
  In this case `b.require` pushes a row like `{id: 'DEP', file: './dep'}`. Even though it has resolved the pathname, module-deps pushes a row with the same props. `json` pipeline phase is unable to recognize it as JSON.
- If I do `browserify().require({file: './dep', expose: 'DEP'})` I get `SyntaxError: Unexpected token`.
  
  `b.require()` pushes a row like `{file: './dep', id: {file: './dep'}}`. Even though it has resolved the pathname, module-deps pushes a row with the same props. `json` pipeline phase is unable to recognize it as JSON.
- If I do `browserify().require({id: './dep', expose: 'DEP'})` I get no error (and the `json` pipeline transform has been applied). Passing an object with an `id` prop is not documented, so take this one for what it's worth. But plugins may have an interest in pushing / modifying rows, so understanding what these props are for and how to use them throughout the pipeline is important. The browserify handbook includes an example of reading / writing `rec.id` during the `deps` / `label` phases.
  
  `b.require()` pushes a row like `{id: './dep'}`. module-deps pushes a row like `{id: './dep', file: '/abs/path/to/dep.json'}`. `json` pipeline phase recognizes it as JSON. 
- In the `label` pipeline phase, the array of external modules is searched for both values.

title: Browserify should probably exclude/require nested packages automatically
Throttle/Debounce with Browserify
Load My Own Modules Using Browserify
Pipeline core sub-phases should be addressable by something "permanent"
body:
I mean I think it should be possible to do something like one of the following:

``` js
// Just add a label
b.pipeline.get('deps').get('module-deps')
b.pipeline.get('deps').get('deps')
b.pipeline.get('deps').get('default')

// Add a label and make labeled-stream-splicer's `get()` like stream-splicer's
b.pipeline.get('deps', 'module-deps')
b.pipeline.get('deps', 'deps')
b.pipeline.get('deps', 'default')

// Add an abstract method that'll return the original phase. What about if
// there's more than 1 core sub-phase though? Like there is for `deps` if
// opts.exposeAll == true
b.pipeline.get('deps').getDefault()
```

Or are people extending browserify supposed to rely on the properties like `b._mdeps` and `b._bpack` for this? They don't appear to be documented, and there aren't props like that set for each core sub-phase.

Say I'm developing a plugin and I need to get at browser-pack, e.g. the equivalent of doing `browserify().pipeline.get('pack').get(0)`. If in my plugin I naively do `b.pipeline.get('pack').get(0)` there's no telling what I'll get, because another plugin may have done something like `b.pipeline.get('pack').unshift()`.

I'm requesting feedback on what the label / mechanism for getting at these phases should be.

FWIW this came to my attention while working on a plugin where I need to be able to set `pipeline.get('pack').get(0).hasExports`.

title: How to supply all files as an object?
Is there a way to specify a file extension to be treated like json
body:
I have avro files that are just json.  browserify I believe is detecting json files and wrapping them in module.exports

Is there a way to say treat *.avsc like json?

title: Document how to load a polyfill in Browserify
body:
Hi,

I have not found any good reference explaining how to load a polyfill into a Browserify app.

I think polyfills must be loaded before other libs as some libs require the polyfill to be present when initialized to work correctly.

This is the case for exemple for FormatJS.io which may require Intl polyfill.

I think the way to go is to use `bundle.add("polyfill")` as we want to load the polyfill without having to require it, but in case multiple `bundle.add` are present, can we assume that the entry points will be loaded in order so that we are sure the polyfills are all loaded even before our app entry point is loaded?

This would be nice to document it, as many people may want to load polyfills into browserify apps.

I've explained how I solved my problem on SO: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27870974/what-is-the-correct-way-to-load-polyfills-and-shims-with-browserify/28964831
But would also like to know if it's a good way to deal with polyfills.

`sam@sam-AY747AA-ABA-p6310y:/usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/example/api/browser$ browserify main.js -o bundle.js
sam@sam-AY747AA-ABA-p6310y:/usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/example/api/browser$`

as you can see, after trying to execute the command, it simply took me back to the neutral terminal command. if i could get any tips on fixing this, that would be great!

title: Enhancement: Display Monolog JSON logfiles as interactive logfilter (Concept)
body:
Monolog is well on it's way to become the default logger for us.

We should start thinking about how to be able to read them as well. Proper filtering is of paramount importance.

Every line has the following:

``` json
{
    "message":"",
    "level":100,
    "level_name":"DEBUG",
    "channel":"Homeportal",
    "datetime":{"date":"2015-03-06 11:39:44.103367","timezone_type":3,"timezone":"Europe\/London"},
}
```

FIltering on all these fields is vital.

Additionally I'm proposing three context standards:
- tags
- function
- class

I made one very special type which is similar to the old API_LOG_FILE.
Often we are interested in only interaction between coursepro and homeportal (Because it is a very compressed representation of what is actually going on)

title: browserifyV9.0.3 does not respect --ignore-missing
body:
After a very frustrating experience, it has come to my attention that browserify no longer respects --ignore missing. What is not clear is whether or not this feature was removed intentionally or not.

There exists a test here for ignoreMissing: https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/47c6933e711567de761c73fe81165223c7873433/test/ignore_missing.js

Also, ignore missing is accepted as a command line argument here: https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/bin/args.js#L87

I see no mention of `ignoreMissing` in `index.js`, so it appears that this feature was removed. Can someone shed some light as to the status of this feature? The documentation still explicitly mentions it with no mention of deprecation.
